Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ImageQuest: Citizens Advancing Biology with Calibrated Imaging and Validated Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Washington University, the University of Arizona, University of California San Diego, and the University of Vermont are awarded collaborative grants to develop tools that support deeper integration of citizen scientists with a broader range of biological imaging projects. Our specific aims are to develop tools (1) to make it easier for volunteers with smart phones to capture calibrated imagery supporting quantitative data measurements, (2) to facilitate volunteer contributions to image analysis tasks with better interfaces and formal methods to validate and create consensus estimates from many responses, and (3) to foster long-term motivation and engagement within virtual communities through online environments that combine aesthetics, social networking and visualization tools. These tools will have an initial focus on problem domains including monitoring of urban re-forestation efforts and analysis of 3D biological and neurological imaging data at many different scales. It will produce a set of smart phone and web apps that will be available to the broader biological research community that require calibrated image capture and analysis, and will create an experimental web portal to engage virtual communities of volunteers and scientists collaborating to work on imaging problems.

The ImageQuest project will make it simpler for volunteers and scientists to engage in a much broader set of biological imaging research. Providing tools which enhance a volunteers ability to capture and analyze images relieves a technical burden on biologists trying to develop citizen science approaches. Making these tools smarter and more interactive encourages volunteers to contribute meaningfully to novel research questions, and building a virtual community around the volunteers and the scientists helps to recruit, motivate and retain long term participation of the public in scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ImageQuest: Citizens Advancing Biology with Calibrated Imaging and Validated Analysis is a collaboration between researchers at Washington University St. Louis, University of Vermont, University of Arizona and University of North Texas. The project researched mechanisms and developed tools to advance citizen science contributions to biological imaging projects by motivating ongoing, continued engagement in such projects in addition to carrying out more quantitative measurements from voluntarily contributed images through calibrated data capture and data annotation. We developed use cases at two distinct scales that represent key research domains in the biological sciences: mapping cells and organs and ecological landscape mapping and monitoring. The rePhoto smartphone app (http://projectrephoto.com) we developed is currently being used by researchers and citizen scientists around the world to monitor changing landscapes.: http://projectrephoto.com. 2) VolumeViewer (http://volumeviewer.cse.wustl.edu/VolumeViewer/Home.html), a freely available tool, is helping improve the accuracy and efficiency of extracting information from 3D biological data used in the medical sciences. We conducted numerous case studies that advanced the techniques for automatically extracting biological information from overhead imaging in support of urban planning. These approaches have been used throughout the United States and Canada to develop an understanding of green infrastructure and establish urban tree canopy goals. Our techniques for collecting accurate geo-information on trees in urban areas were used in the 2015 New York City Tree Census, the most detailed tree survey ever conducted for NYC, which was carried out largely by volunteers.

This research has provided hands-on research, data analysis, and critical/analytical thinking training and expertise to graduate and undergraduate students in multiple disciplines contributing to development of a STEM-capable workforce. Additionally, multiple peer-reviewed journal articles, outreach presentations and implementations of our tools have provided exposure to advanced science and technology to diverse public audiences that would not have otherwise been exposed to this kind of cross-disciplinary science and thus enhanced public understanding of and interest in interdisciplinary research and science.
